If it helps anyone, I achieved the above using `mod_unique_id` and `mod_headers`:

```
RequestHeader setifempty X-B3-TraceId "expr=%{md5:%{reqenv:UNIQUE_ID}}"
RequestHeader edit X-B3-TraceId "^(.{0,16}).*$" "$1"
```

`%{reqenv:UNIQUE_ID}` is a unique string generated by mod_unique_id. Then, it gets MD5-hashed and assigned to the `X-B3-TraceId` header. This gives a 32-character hex string = 128 bit traceId. Since my downstream libraries require the traceIds to be 64-bit, the `RequestHeader edit` extracts the first 16 characters (64 bit) from the value and reassigns it back to the `X-B3-TraceId` header which is sent downstream.
awesome thanks for sharing @adammichalik!

The only impact this could have wrt presentations is if we want the charts to also show how many downstream/exit spans per service. I think we can wait for that, as it would layer on this if we did it as opposed to invalidate it.

cat /opt/kafka/./data/kafka/meta.properties

#Mon Aug 31 12:46:30 GMT 2020

cluster.id=2eUVIKyFQM2YWzayeONBzw

PS I overcomplicated the algo I think. With the special case of the root span localEndpoint.serviceName needing to be counted regardless, all we have to do is count dependencyLink.child where child in *.localEndpoint.serviceName

@jcchavezs Thank you so much!

> Someone who uses Zipkin on a regular basis should probably chime in on whether the service names being visible or not (without mousing over) affects their usual workflow (e.g. ctrl+F search in page for service... though I guess this is what the filter mentioned above is for).

I'm still curious about this, but don't let my theoretical concern stop progress here if others are happy with the change. Compared to before, it is an extra click and mouseover away from seeing what the count is for a given service in a trace and if you are looking for the count of a particular service (theoretical use case: looking for traces where a service was called many times? or no times) you only have the first letter to figure out where to mouseover.

I see... ðŸ¤” 
I have two ideas..

* Add ~"Collapse All"~ "Expand All" button
* Add small tables under bar chart for showing complete service name and span count.

![ã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒªãƒ¼ãƒ³ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒƒãƒˆ 2020-09-01 19 10 48](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19551419/91837847-8d162400-ec87-11ea-92b8-2de46c307bd2.png)

## User scenario

1. Push "RUN QUERY" button
2. Filter services using Service Filter
3. If the user want to narrow down search more, push ~"COLLAPSE ALL"~ "Expand All" button.
4. All service name & span count chart and table will appear.
5. Then, the user can ctrl-F search (because the table displays complete service names).

What do you think? @shakuzen

PS the original design idea for the letters was that services that shared a same first letter would be grouped. The bar chart would not have X axis ordered by span count, rather by letters like books on a shelf. 

When you see a tall letter (high span count) you click into it and see which of the N services that might be there.

This is imperfect idea, as service names are neither always starting with a letter, nor are they distributed across the letters. However, it was an idea to allow you to browse a trace that has an extreme amount of service names in a way besides wrapping 20 times.

The design drifted a little from that which might not be bad, but it lost the impact of the grouping. You can see in the images the same letter repeated as it is now ordered by span count. If we go back to this then we can consider trying labels instead of the first letter or something else.

cc also @bulicekj 

PS anyone with a massive amount of (but valid) service name trace would be appreciated, cc @narayaruna @drolando @llinder also would be their feedback.

FWIW I think in practice this is showing that really large traces may have slightly different visual needs than smaller ones. If you have less than 10 service names, I think there's no point grouping at all, or even abbreviating. That said service names that are really long will always have a problem as their labels mess up things.

> Would you prefer ES_TEMPLATE_PRIORITY= <--- (aka null) to default to 0,
> instead of using legacy template? With the type set to nullable Integer, if
> the ES_TEMPLATE_PRIORITY is not integer (ES_TEMPLATE_PRIORITY=asfsd, for
> instance), Spring will throw error and fail start up. Andif
> ES_TEMPLATE_PRIORITY= (null), then legacy template will be used.
>
The main impact is the yml file which defaults this as then a user doesn't
need to know how it becomes null just how to make it not null :)

If spring has a way to represent a null integer, then I would recommend
using that in the template-priority ${ES_TEMPLATE_PRIORITY:XXXXXX} part for
XXXXXX
In any case a spring properties test can ensure however we are getting to a
null templatePriority works, in case spring boot changes their mind next
version about how to default things.. it will be caught.

First, let's remember this is about testing not releasing. so building an image on PR and testing that.

> What's the "separate project"?

Sorry I meant separate maven module, similar to benchmarks, that doesn't need to execute, but is coherent (same versions etc.. linked to parent pom). Whether it is linked or not to the parent pom may change depending on how we proceed.. For example, if we break the flow such that maven doesn't control making the images later tested.. then there's I suppose not much point in having this linked.

>> docker action instead of maven plugin...

hmm so if I understand correctly, you mean to start the flow with docker action, then run mvn to run the docker tests, as opposed to implicitly doing that with a docker plugin.

## flow option 1: use maven the whole way (when in maven)

1. docker action runs maven to..
  1. run normal server build
  2. uses plugin to build Dockerfile using the built jar
  3. executes testcontainers tests

change needed: small change to Dockerfile to use zipkin exec jar built by maven

pros:
 * use can fire and forget (execute one command and come back later)
 * IDE is aware of everything
cons:
 * If the docker plugin becomes abandoned, this has to be revisited
 * a change to the Dockerfile is needed, even if it is a small one
 * unless you break the maven build into two github action steps, caching/resume would be too coarse grained
 * the docker parts are implicit so less easy to see in the github action steps

## flow option 2: flip between docker action and maven

1. docker action step builds Dockerfile (which internally runs maven build)
2. docker action step runs maven to execute testcontainers tests

pros:
 * docker steps use official action
 * don't need to use a 3rd party maven plugin for docker
cons:
 * IDE has no link from source built to image built (refactoring etc)
 * it is strange to explain that docker build runs the same build internally, then later we run maven externally to test that image

I'm missing pros and cons on either but trying to spike some rationale. definitely I think the latter feels very weird to me, basically the inception part of docker running maven then for maven to run tests on the docker image
Ah maven plugin would let the tests build the images in IDE too - it's like gradle docker plugin ðŸ˜‹ That's a big advantage for the plugin approach.
neat thing is we can have multiple actions anyway :) so we could test both approaches heh

yep IDE is convenient, and relevant when the images are actually tested in there :)

note: I have no plans to use any sort of plugin based dockerfile generation thingies that may or may not exist as that doesn't allow "normal docker" to work later.

Ex. we still have to allow maven-in-docker for dockerhub builds to work (status quo), as I presume we did that earlier in order to not have to worry what kind of image dockerhub uses for web hooks. In fact, I should reverse that rationale as it is very subtle!
note: I still owe a change to make those numbers better (#3192).. we should be counting entry spans (local roots) not ad-hoc spans. That said, the UX wouldn't change

BTW have you considered using Testcontainers alone to build & test the image?
https://www.testcontainers.org/features/creating_images/

Thanks for the continued effort and design work here, @tacigar. Great stuff! In a lot of ways, I like this much more. I worry, though, if we don't make it clear that the pie chart is showing span count, users will think it is a representation of relative duration. Even if we tried to make it clear, I worry if users will still jump to that conclusion. Likewise, the table with the span count almost aligns with the duration column from the search results, which again might lead people to think it is a duration value. I wonder if we need both the pie chart and the table, since the names of the services are clearly visible on the pie chart. Depending on how important seeing the exact numbers are, maybe just a pie chart is enough?

I'll also note that in design cases we aren't using a trace with a large amount of service names. The earlier design (bucketing by first letter) could equally be done in pie form, as could bars without bucketing by service name. I think we are still in need of a representative trace that has a lot of service names in it. @mrajah-twttr would you be up to contributing a realistic trace with a larger amount of service names in it?
typically we have large number of spans and not large number of services.. how many services are you looking at

> typically we have large number of spans and not large number of services.. how many services are you looking at

any trace with more than 20 service names would cause some design impact I think
ok ready!
